item.title: [Itrfoundation] Dreaming of a White Christmas? Vermont Taxpayers Are Facing a Different Forecast
item.description:
Vermont is facing a projected 12% property tax increase, driven by declining student enrollment and rapidly escalating public education spending—now over $29,000 per pupil.
Lawmakers passed Act 73 to restructure the education system and reduce long-term costs, but disagreements remain over school consolidation and implementation, while other states like Wisconsin, New Hampshire, and South Dakota are considering similar reforms.
The Vermont experience shows that buying down taxes with surplus funds does not solve underlying funding problems, and provides a warning to states like Iowa that durable property tax relief depends on structural reform and spending restraint—not temporary patches.

item.title: [Itrfoundation] A Decade in the Making, a Reform Worth Protecting
item.description:
Iowa’s 3.8% flat tax is the culmination of a decade-long reform effort, beginning in 2018, made possible by conservative budgeting, spending restraint, and structural tax reforms, not a one-time tax cut or temporary policy experiment. A flat tax is fairer, simpler, and more transparent than a progressive system, treating taxpayers equally under a single rate while preserving deductions and credits that protect lower-income households. To preserve its economic and fiscal benefits, Iowa’s flat tax must be constitutionally protected, ensuring long-term competitiveness, predictable budgeting, and preventing future legislatures from reversing course with higher progressive or wealth taxes.

The post A Decade in the Making, a Reform Worth Protecting appeared first on ITR Foundation.

item.title: [Itrfoundation] Andrew Mellon Would Reform Property Taxes with Spending Limits
item.description:
Andrew Mellon believed durable tax reform requires spending restraint and debt reduction first, arguing that balanced budgets, and not higher tax rates, are essential to long-term prosperity and revenue stability.
Mellon warned that high tax rates discourage investment, encourage avoidance, and ultimately harm economic growth while failing to deliver the promised revenue gains.
His principles offer clear guidance for Iowa today: limit government spending, apply tax relief broadly rather than selectively, and recognize that lower tax burdens can strengthen economic growth without a harmful reduction in revenues.
